title: What scientific revolution happened in Asia? - Quora

response.answer_text: “What scientific revolution happened in Asia?” There was no more a scientific revolution in Asia than there was in Europe. It’s been a long evolution of several thousand years. Much of the early development of science was in Asia. Sumerian then Babylonian, Egyptian, Indian, Persian and others. Some early development also happened in Greece and other parts of Europe and northern Africa. The so-called “Scientific Revolution” in Europe is a hagiographic fantasy about science by historians with limited understanding of science. The period it describes was largely one of Europeans catching up with science from elsewhere. It’s standard definition is the 150 years between the publication of Copernicus’ book and the publication of Newtons’ Principia Mathematica yet Copernicus’ work was based on earlier Greek work and Newton’s science still fell short of the the rigour of modern scientific method. Aside of which, what kind of “revolution” is a gradual change over 150 years? Science is still evolving. All over the world. There was no scientific revolution in Asia any more than there was in Europe.
